Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the father needs to provide it
Expectation2: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation2: The mentor arranged a short meeting in an otherwise packed day.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the screen glowing with a message from my mentor: “I can meet for 20 minutes at 2 PM. It’s the only slot I have today.” My heart thudded. That same hour, my wife had asked me to visit the bank to sort out a payment issue—without it, we wouldn’t have enough for groceries this week. As a father, I felt the weight of my family’s needs pressing down on me. I knew how much they depended on me to keep things afloat, to make sure there was food on the table and bills were paid on time.

But as a mentee, I also felt the responsibility to respect my mentor’s time. He was busy, and this meeting was a rare chance to get his guidance—something I desperately needed for my career. I could almost hear his voice in my head, reminding me how important it was to be reliable and committed.

I sat at the kitchen table, torn between the urgent needs of my family and the rare opportunity to learn from someone I admired. My hands trembled as I weighed the expectations, feeling the pressure build with every passing minute.
